utterances: Well, this is a great essay.

Ryan from Anchorage, Alaska joined us today from the last frontier and we thank him for his time.
And, joining is now is Randall Kenan, who teaches creative writing at the University of North Carolina, and wrote an essay about his home state North Carolina for the anthology.
He joins us from Hillsborough, North Carolina.
Randall Kennan, nice to have you with us, Happy Thanksgiving.
Happy Thanksgiving to you, delighted to be here.
And you wrote a story, an essay about pigs and neo pigs and barbecue.
Yes.
Yes.
At first, I thought I might do something on banking or biotech, that's what the future of the state looks to be but hogs and pork seemed to capture that past, the present and the future.
You tell an absolutely hilarious story about growing up the street from, was it your uncle's farm?
Yeah.
Well, my cousin yes, yes, yes.
And his kids and all of you learning about, well the facts of life from hogs.
That is one of those facts of being a farm boy is that you learn early and often right before your eyes.
And, then you go on to tell us the neo-pork story about how one who man grew up not very far away from where you grew up has change that face of the state?
Yes, it was in the same county Duplin County, in south eastern North Carolina.
A man who would go on to make a billion dollars on pork.
A man named Wendell Murphy.
He sort of turned a pork production into a something like a factory operation.
And, then you go on and talk about how - well, you suggest - speaking of corruption, that he may have influence the state legislature to overlook certain problems that his industry has created.
Well, it's an ongoing story, and he - his aren't the only hands.
I mean, the state legislature - it can be implicated is certainly now for not enforcing the laws.
But hog waste in particular, it has become a huge problem at the state let affecting our ecosystem in a really awful way.

And finally, you write and I'm quoting here, ""I am as partisan as they come and do not apologize to any man, woman or child, the best barbecue in the world comes from North Carolina, and not just anywhere in North Carolina from the eastern part of the state.
Well, I think that is a signal part of being a North Carolinian is that you have to take part in the barbecue wars.
And the east, the Piedmont, and the mountains, we all have our particular type of barbecue.
And coming from the southeast, I have to you know, claim my loyalty and my tastebuds are in line with that.
You write that those who come from the other parts of the states are heathens on such matters, and should be attended to as one way to attend a young child.
They know not what they do.
God bless them.
God bless them.
They you know they'll learn one day.
One day they'll learn.
Pork and hogs are - the - more, more pigs than people in North Carolina.
I didn't know that.
Well, in fact, I recently found a statistic that in my home county which is quite small, they're over two million hogs.
That's 40 hogs per person.
40 hogs per person.
Exactly.
That's a lot of barbecue.
That is a lot of pork.
Yes sir.
Randall Kennan, have a happy - are you having a barbecue for this Thanksgiving?
A barbecued turkey and a few other pork products.
Thanks very much.
Have a great holiday.

Randall Kennan, a professor of creative writing at UNC-Chapel Hill, his essay on North Carolina again in ""State by State: A Panoramic Portrait of America."" He joined us today by phone from Hillsborough, North Carolina, his home.
And we should add, there are of course 50 states to choose from.
Those we picked reveal some bias.

Vincent with us from Salem in Oregon.
Hi.
I'm actually not a Oregon native originally.
I'm originally from Maui in Hawaii, and unfortunately Hawaii s just kind of pushed off to the side on the holidays, because it's the 50th state.
We're out in the middle of the ocean.
And nobody has, you know, barbecued ne-ne (ph) for a Thanksgiving.
Oh, thank God no. There's always about 1,500 of those birds left.
So I mean you got to watch for them, but we do have turkey, and we do have yams, and we do have all the other things that you would expect.
But, we also have things that you wouldn't expect like barbecued o peehee(ph), so this little cone shaped mollusks.
That you put a little garlic and some butter on, and you eat those as kind of an appetizer.
Or, lomi-lomi salmon and right next to the cranberry sauce and the turkey.
And so, I mean, it's very different.
I mean, I remember going up to my uncle's house.
And he lives in a place on Maui called Bolinda(ph).
And you're surrounded by eucalyptus trees and pine, and you just got this real woody forest smell, but every once in a while you get this wafted(ph), salt ocean smell too.
We hope the ne-ne will grow and thrive, and develop into great flocks but it will, no matter what happens, live forever in crossword puzzle clues as Hawaiian goose.
Exactly, and what's really funny those, it's not a native itself.
Actually there's - it was a Canada goose that got lost and so, it's kind of how it got there.

So you didn't have a cell phone in that backpack that you rescued.
